awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Design of Legal Power in Authoritarian Regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
Stable governance in developing countries, especially in nascent democracies with long histories of authoritarian rule, is a national security interest of the United States. While rule of law is considered a hallmark of stable governance, it is often lacking in these regions. Over the past half-century, American efforts to build democratic rule of law in developing countries have encountered limited successes and repeated failures. This project aims to uncover the origins of undemocratic legal systems in the developing world and why they are so resistant to reform during transitions to more democratic governance by focusing on the institutional choices made by governments during key periods of authoritarian consolidation. During the early years of dictatorship, some dictators confer legal authority to the formal judiciary, while others choose to erect ad hoc legal forums. These decisions have lasting legacies in determining the locus of judicial authority in developing countries, which ultimately affects how justice operates and who it ultimately serves. This has further implications for the protection of human rights under dictatorship. For American policymakers, identifying the stakeholders in authoritarian legal systems is thus an imperative first step towards creating effectively targeted reforms and building democratic rule of law abroad.

To understand how authoritarian legal systems in developing countries have emerged and evolved over time, this project utilizes mixed-methods analysis that combines both qualitative process-tracing techniques and statistical analysis. Original data will be gathered from British and American archives containing records on the political and legal development of developing countries in Sub-Saharan Africa and Southeast Asia. Archival research will leverage a variety of underutilized historical documents -- including party documents, official correspondences, judicial registers, court rulings, and memoires -- to understand how legal institutional design emerged and evolved across a large portion of the developing world. Using process-tracing techniques, case studies of countries such as Malawi, Kenya, and Burma will provide insight into how legal and authoritarian power was structured in the postcolonial period, and also examine how early legal decisions had lasting legacies that persist until today. Archival data will also be instrumental in creating an original cross-national dataset of cases that have been adjudicated in a variety of legal forums. This dataset, covering the period from independence to the modern day, will help identify generalizable patterns of legal decision-making across countries and over time. 

This research project contributes to the understanding of authoritarian legal systems and the consolidation of dictatorships across a large portion of the developing world. It will deepen theoretical and empirical understanding of these themes in three important ways. First, it will help identify how despotic power can have long-lasting effects on the design and operation of legal institutions, even after the transition to democracy. Second, it will draw attention to the political effects of legal institutions in countries of Sub-Saharan-Africa and Southeast Asia, regions that have become critical economic and diplomatic partners of the United States. Third, it will provide new data on legal design from a critical period of nation-building in developing countries that can be employed for other studies extending beyond the scope of this project. This data will be made publicly available upon publication of the findings.

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of the project was to uncover the origins of undemocratic legal systems in the developing world and understand why they are resistant to reform during transitions to more democratic governance. The project specifically focused on institutional choices made by governments during key periods of authoritarian consolidation, identifying important parallels between the design of legal institutions and the ways in which despotic power is shared across different branches of government. Focusing on the experience of former British colonies in sub-Saharan Africa, the project addressed how these factors underpinned the design of judiciaries and the course of justice over time. By understanding these intertwined processes and their role in fortifying autocratic rule, the project also aimed to show how rule of law under dictatorship affects the long-term operation of law and order in post-autocratic periods.

The grant was primarily used to collect original data on the design, operation, and long-term impact of legal and justice institutions in former British colonies across sub-Saharan Africa. The vast majority of archival research was conducted at the British National Archives in London, United Kingdom, which houses abundant records pertaining to the colonial and post-colonial governance of all former British colonies. Additional archival research was conducted at the British Library in London, United Kingdom as well as the Honourable Society of the Inner Temple, London, United Kingdom. 

The grant was also used to travel to Malawi where the co-PI was able to personally interview Supreme Court justices, High Court judges, High Court registrars, the President and founder of the Malawi Law Society, human rights lawyers, and constitutional scholars. The co-PI also collected data from legal archives in Blantyre and Zomba, Malawi.

This project contributes to the understanding of authoritarian legal systems and the consolidation of dictatorships across a large portion of the developing world, issues that are of critical interest to political scholars. Political scientists have begun focusing attention on the institutional tactics of leaders in authoritarian regimes, in particular the ways in which legal institutions such as constitutions or courts are used by autocrats to fortify their claims to power. In line with these trends, this project will deepen understanding of how law operates in authoritarian regimes in three important ways: first, by demonstrating important parallels between the design of legal institutions and the ways in which despotic power is shared across different branches of government; second, by collecting and analyzing original data on legal institutional design from a critical period of nation-buiding in the developing world; third, by drawing attention to legal institutions in Africa and Southeast Asia, which remain understudied in political science.

The findings from this project have important ramifications for other disciplines, including legal studies, criminology, and history. Archival research produced original data on political prosecutions for 7 African countries across a 50-year time period, illustrating broad, generalizable patterns of criminal justice for developing countries during a critical period of regime development. In particular, this historical data, which is unique in its scope and detail, highlights important variation in the trial, verdicts, and sentencing of alleged political offenders, which deepens theoretical and empirical understanding of how law is used by state actors to legitimize powerholders while delegitimizing the opposition. By focusing on sub-Saharan Africa, this project extends understanding of criminal justice and its political uses to an understudied region of the developing world, which enriches existing theories in legal studies and crimonology.

This project also has implications for historical research. In particular, this research analyzes archival documents using modern computer processing techniques, providing new ways of efficiently synthesizing historical information. Thousands of primary text documents were digitized and processed in Python programming language, which ultimately revealed new ways of representing qualitative information en masse, identifying semantic patterns in the corpus that might not have been apparent had each text had been analyzed individually. Applying “big data” research techniues to historical data illustrates new ways of quantifying qualitative information, which is of critical interest to scholars of the digital humanities. This project thus contributes to modern methods of empirical research for scholars in multiple disciplines.

Finally, this project contributes to broader theories of law and order in repressive societies, which is relevant for both scholars of authoritarian regimes and government policymakers working to build rule of law in developing contexts. As the past several decades of international legal aid have made clear, understanding where legal institutions come from is a necessary first step towards enacting sustainable reforms. The findings on the historical origins of legal orders will thus benefit rule-of-law practitioners working in illiberal societies. By directing attention to patterns of legal consolidation and fragmentation, this project will also help policymakers identify the locus of legal authority and thus target their reforms efficiently, a critical issue that has plagued many rule-of-law projects over the past decade.
